hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Khuzayma ibn Thabit: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ purchased a horse from Sawaa' ibn Qais al-Muharabi, but he denied it. Khuzayma ibn Thabit testified for him. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said to him: What compelled you to bear witness when you were not present with us? He said: I believed you by what you brought, and I knew that you do not say except the truth. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: Whoever Khuzayma testifies for him, or testifies against him, it is sufficient for him.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Khuzayma ibn Thabit: A man came to Muhammad ibn Ka'b and asked him, O Abu Hamza, what do you see regarding coming to my wife from the back? He turned away from him and said, Be silent. He said, This is the elder of Quraysh, ask him, meaning Abdullah ibn Ali. Abdullah ibn Ali ibn al-Sa'ib said, May Allah make it repulsive, even if it were lawful. He said: Then he informed me, then Abdullah ibn Ali ibn al-Sa'ib informed me that he met Amr ibn Uhayha ibn al-Julah, so he asked him: Have you heard anything regarding coming to women from their backs? He said: I swear by Allah, I heard Khuzayma ibn Thabit, the one whom Allah's Messenger made his testimony equal to the testimony of two men, that a man came to the Prophet ﷺ and said: O Messenger of Allah, I come to my wife from the back. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: Yes, he said it twice or three times. Then the Messenger of Allah ﷺ understood what he meant and said: As for in her back in her front, then yes. As for in her back, then no. Indeed, Allah the Mighty and Majestic forbids you from coming to women in their backs.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Khuzayma ibn Thabit: I heard the Messenger of Allah ﷺ saying: Indeed, Allah the Mighty and Majestic does not feel shy from the truth. Do not come to women in their rear parts. Ibn Abi Asim said: And it was narrated by Ali ibn Abdullah from Harmi, from Khuzayma. And it was narrated by Ibn al-Hadi from Ubayd Allah ibn Abdullah ibn al-Husain from Harmi ibn Abdullah al-Waqifi from Khuzayma, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet ﷺ. And it was narrated by Ibn al-Hadi from Umarah ibn Khuzayma from the Prophet ﷺ. And it has multiple paths from Khuzayma.

hadiths.english_translation: This entry contains three separate narrations from al-Bara' ibn 'Azib: (1) 'I and Ibn Umar were presented to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ on the Day of Badr, but he considered us too young, and we witnessed Uhud.' (2) 'When the Messenger of Allah ﷺ raised his head from bowing, none of us would bend his back (to prostrate) until he prostrated, and when he prostrated, we would follow him.' (3) 'We were with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ on a journey, and we came to a shallow well. Six or seven people descended, I being the sixth or seventh, to draw water. They lowered a bucket to me while the Messenger of Allah ﷺ was at the edge of the well. We filled it half or about two-thirds. I raised it to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, and I could hardly find anything to put in my mouth. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ dipped his hands in it and said what Allah willed him to say. The bucket was returned to us with water in it. I saw the last of us come out with his garment for fear of drowning, and the well overflowed.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Fadalah ibn 'Ubayd: He said: We went on the expedition of Tabuk with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, and the riding animals became extremely exhausted. They complained to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ about the exhaustion of their animals. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ began to breathe upon their backs and say: 'O Allah, carry them in Your way, for indeed You carry the strong and the weak, the fresh and the withered, on land and on sea.' We did not reach Medina until they (the animals) were pulling on their reins with vigor. Fadalah said: This was the supplication of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ for the strong and the weak, so what about the fresh and the withered? When we reached Syria, we went on the expedition to Cyprus by sea, and I recognized the supplication of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ (as applying to sea travel as well).
